html.p: What: outputs events/rows/whatever as a csv file in the "lookups" directory.

ol.li: Can be used with inputlookup to read that back off disk
Or can be used with lookup itself to enrich
If you want to use it as a lookup 'automatically' then you'll have to go the whole route of specifying the lookup definition etc. And you probably should anyway.
Other options, like appending or overwriting, available too in the docs.

html.p: Why: Quick way to temporarily save off "slower" search output to work on and test with.
So What: We'll use it a lot in here.
The data output we build here will be used in a lot of succeeding commands, so please be sure to do this one!
html.pre: | makeresults format=csv data="offset, salesperson, cars -10800, Rich, 1 -10800, David, 1 -7200, Rich, 0 -7200, David, 0 -3600, Rich, 1 -3600, David, 2 -0, Rich, 2 -0, David, 3" | eval _time = now() - offset | rename cars AS cars_this_hour | table _time, salesperson, cars_this_hour

search.query: | makeresults format=csv data="offset, salesperson, cars -10800, Rich, 1 -10800, David, 1 -7200, Rich, 0 -7200, David, 0 -3600, Rich, 1 -3600, David, 2 -0, Rich, 2 -0, David, 3" | eval _time = now() - offset | rename cars AS cars_this_hour | table _time, salesperson, cars_this_hour

html.p: Adding | outputlookup $moniker$_rich_and_dave_cars.csv to the end. NOTE that it's an "unsafe command" so you'll have to click the warning triangle to allow it!

p.strong: ALSO be sure to fill in a name above (unique!) before running this!

search.query: | makeresults format=csv data="offset, salesperson, cars -10800, Rich, 1 -10800, David, 1 -7200, Rich, 0 -7200, David, 0 -3600, Rich, 1 -3600, David, 2 -0, Rich, 2 -0, David, 3" | eval _time = now() - offset | table _time, salesperson, cars | rename cars AS "Cars Sold This Hour" | outputlookup $moniker$_rich_and_dave_cars.csv

html.h1: The next command, inputlookup, will show you one way to read prove this worked by reading the values back in.
